column7: We are taking proactive measures to prepare and respond in anticipation of the impending changes in sustainability reporting and disclosure. The introduction and adoption of ISSB standards will enable investors and other stakeholders to make more informed decisions by providing a standardised framework for evaluating sustainability and climate-related information. This development is particularly advantageous for BramblesÃ¢ÂÂ low-carbon, circular business, as it highlights our strategic advantages and opportunities as our stakeholders push for a faster transition to a sustainable economic model.
Our commitment is to be Planet Positive by restoring forests, going beyond zero waste and drawing down more carbon than we produce, ultimately becoming a regenerative, nature-positive business.

Brambles is committed to operating in an environment where our business and key suppliers act with honesty, integrity, fairness and accountability. These principles are key to our success, core to protecting supply chains and central to our efforts to serve our stakeholders.

column13: Brambles continuously assesses risk, supported by Group Risk, Internal Audit, and Global Compliance functions. The following governance and controls guide this process: Code Of Conduct And Group Policies, Privacy and Information Security, Third Party Due Diligence And Human Rights Programme Speak Up, Reward And Remediation Programme Compliance Assessments, Monitoring, And Auditing.
column20: Risk management, Governance controls, Compliance frameworks

column7: The Code provides a foundation for Brambles' ethical conduct. It is one way Brambles incorporates its Shared Values into its businesses. The Code describes how Brambles relates to its employees, customers and suppliers, shareholders, and the communities in which it operates and where its employees and key stakeholders live and work. The Code of Conduct provides an ethical and legal framework for all employees in the conduct of BramblesÃ¢ÂÂ business.

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column7: You can always speak to your supervisor or management when you believe Wrongdoing has occurred. In situations where you believe our Code of Conduct has been violated. Where you prefer to place a report confidently, you are encouraged to use this EthicsPoint hotline hosted by NAVEX, an independent third-party hotline provider. You can also use this hotline to report any other concerns, provide suggestions or feedbackÃ¢ÂÂwhether positive or negativeÃ¢ÂÂor ask questions about our policies and procedures.

Brambles operates in many countries with widely differing legal regimes, legislative requirements, and compliance cultures. In addition, the regulatory landscape continues to evolve rapidly in areas such as privacy, human rights, and ESG-related matters. Failure to comply with regulatory obligations and local laws could adversely affect BramblesÃ¢ÂÂ operational and financial performance and reputation.

The GroupÃ¢ÂÂs operations are subject to numerous environmental laws and regulations in the other countries in which it operates. There were no material breaches of these laws or regulations during the Year.

column8: Zero Waste World hosts a Sustainable Brands Member Meeting
column13: The event with the theme 'Good Growth' included executive panels with industry innovators and a CHEP's Innovation Centre tour. Attendees learned about brand transformation and culture change initiatives for good growth.
column20: Corporate events, Industry collaboration, Sustainability partnerships

column13: At the COP27 in Sharm El Sheik, Egypt, our Sustainability and Government Affairs Lead for IMETA, Marietjie Brown, travelled as part of a delegation from South Africa to represent the Alliance for Climate Action. The Alliance is a network of committed organisations working with local and national governments to achieve a net carbon-neutral economy for South Africa by 2050. Brambles and CHEP also joined experts at the South African Pavilion at a panel on 'Closing the Circle: Circular Economy Approaches', sharing best practices from our 'share and reuse' model and ZWW.
column20: COP27 participation, Climate advocacy, Emissions reduction

column13: CHEP Europe developed the Circularity Index to showcase customers' circular performance. It calculates a carbon emission per pallet metric to help communicate circular inefficiencies while encouraging users to achieve an optimum CO2-e per pallet score. The index leverages Brambles' long history of LCA expertise and enables customers to keep pallets cycling in CHEP's circular networks. Engagement efforts have been well received, leading to plans for expansion in other regions.
column20: Circular economy index, Carbon footprint, Environmental impact

column8: Coles and CHEP's Joint Sustainability Roadmap
column13: Coles, one of Australia's largest retailers, and CHEP created a Joint Sustainability Roadmap. Coles achieved logistics decarbonisation by adopting Reclaim Timber Stillage units to collect broken pallet boards and moving from cardboard produce bins to CHEP's reusable options. They also optimised transportation using Coles' store fleet, turning empty return trips into productive lanes, eliminating over 38,000 truck kilometres and 320 tonnes of CO2 emissions in the Victorian State alone.
column20: Retail sustainability partnership, Decarbonization, Circular solutions

column13: The CHEP and RCL Foods partnership promotes sustainability and social wellbeing across the local value chain. Through CHEP's circular model, RCL Foods has achieved remarkable environmental reductions, including 56% CO2 emissions, 71% wood usage, and 59% waste. These reductions are equivalent to saving 8420 trees and 219 truckloads of garbage.
column20: Food industry sustainability, Environmental stewardship, Carbon reduction

column7: In March 2023, Brambles initiated a review of the suite of external reports we produce for our stakeholders. The review included refreshing BramblesÃ¢ÂÂ materiality processes and adopting a double materiality lens. Double materiality refers to how the information disclosed by a company can be material both in terms of its implications for the companyÃ¢ÂÂs financial value, as well as the companyÃ¢ÂÂs impact on global issues such as climate change and other environmental impacts, as well as social and human capital issues.

Climate change impacts (TCFD), Sustainable (business) growth, zero harm, Moving to a climate-neutral circular economy, Social impact of the value chain, Nature and biodiversity interactions, Overuse of the worldÃ¢ÂÂs resources (including raw materials), Work/life balance, Transparency and corporate governance (including anti-corruption and bribery), Learning and development, and Environmental impact of direct operations.\t

column13: The supply chain of the future is built on the innovation of today, and Brambles' Shaping Our Future transformation programme is using our enhanced data analytics capabilities and increasing smart asset innovations to improve our circular model continuously. Asset productivity is the foundation of our circular model. Through our enhanced asset recovery, collection and protection initiatives, pallet remanufacturing activities, and proactive customer engagement, we have recovered and salvaged ~10.12 million pallets in FY23.
column20: Data analytics, Circular model, Asset recovery

column13: Our teams leverage Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) and a leading circular measurement tool to demonstrate the environmental benefits of the 'share and reuse' solutions. It is how we accelerate progress against our customers' circular economy and sustainability commitments.\t

column13: Brambles' low-carbon, circular business model provides a foundation for developing regenerative supply chains. Circularity demonstrates the benefits of resource, decarbonisation, and waste reduction for our customers. Our systems, experience, and supply chain innovations enable circularity. Our people integrate all these elements and are the driving force behind our Business-Positive performance.

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: Brambles completed our first green bond finance offering, the first for an Australian company to be fully dedicated to the circular economy. The eight-year Ã¢ÂÂ¬500 million green bond, with a coupon rate of 4.25%, was issued under Brambles' European Medium Term Note programme and recently published Green Finance Framework, which is aligned with the International Capital Market Association's Green Bond Principles and the Loan Market Association's Green Loan Principles.
column20: Green finance, Circular economy investment, Sustainable bonds

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: Brambles secured a US$1.35bn sustainability-linked loan. The 5-year facility is linked to our sustainability targets, including Brambles' Forest, Climate, Workplace and Waste Positive programmes. ANZ Bank acted as joint sustainability and documentation coordinator on the loan deal, including two one-year extension options subject to the banks' consent.
column20: Sustainability-linked loan, Financial sustainability, ESG financing

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: In FY23, CHEP LATAM launched the VÃÂ­nculos Positivos (Positive Bonds) campaign to drive sustainability partnerships with key accounts and retailers. By showcasing the benefits of our circular model through Sustainability Certificates and connecting with customers on their sustainability journey, these events strengthened a joint sustainability agenda with over 70 customers across Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Central America, and Mexico.
column20: Sustainability partnerships, Circular model showcase, Customer engagement

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column7: Brambles conducted a series of stress tests during FY23 to evaluate the resilience of its networks, which include high-volume service centres and adjacent critical transport infrastructure, against severe weather events. The tests assessed various climate hazards based on historical events by region. The preliminary results indicate that the impacts ranged from minor to significant, depending on factors such as the duration and location of the events.

column6: Defined benefit plan obligations and other retirement plans
Ratios of standard entry level wage by gender compared to local minimum wage
column7: Brambles recognizes that wages are essential to achieving an adequate standard of living. We fully comply with all applicable wage, work hours, overtime and benefits laws, and we recognise that everyone has the right to rest and leisure, including the reasonable limitation of working hours and periodic holidays with pay. Additionally, Brambles aims to do business with suppliers and other third parties who comply with applicable wage, work hours, overtime and benefits laws and agree to ensure transparency, remedy any shortcomings identified, and drive continuous improvement.
